name: rails_money
description: Rails Money Plugin

commit.message:
Add support for validates_numericality_of Money attributes. For example, with a "price_in_cents" column in your model, you can say: validates_numericality_of :price, :greater_than => 0.50 Round tripping via a form works, so something like:

<%= f.label :price %>
<%= f.text_field :price %>

will display the right highlighting if the value is invalid; you'll probably want to override the message, as the values in the default message are unadorned with money formatting: the default message for the above example would be "Price must be greater than 0.5". (If anyone has suggestions on better ways to achieve this, please contact me!) Signed-off-by: Jose Fernandez

Don't git the debug log

name: shoes
description: a tiny graphical app kit for ruby

commit.message: Fix class hierarchy in manual by ignoring mixins in introspection
Build extensions on mac as well as linux

Add an onclose handler so you can get a callback when an App closes.  Could potentially work for
other types of things (dialogs/windows) as well.
Fix bug in cocoa ask_save_file

Fix bug with Shoes::Widget class.  Failing test case this fixes:

class Shoes::Foo < Shoes::Widget
  def initialize text
    para text
  end
end

Shoes.app do
  foo 'success'
  @s = stack do
    para "hovering over this text should print 'fail'"
  end
  @s.hover do
    foo 'fail'
  end
end
* shoes/http/nsurl.m: hang on to header dictionary, only release when the request has started.
* shoes/http/nsurl.m: http error handling for os x.

* shoes/http: allocating event objects, to be more threadsafe. getting http error messages from winhttp.dll.
 * shoes/ruby.c: remove non-threaded handler, we're async only now.

* shoes/ruby.c: send unhandled http errors to the console. HEAD requests don't allocate room for the HTTP body.
 * shoes/http/curl.c: get HEAD requests working.
* shoes/http: free headers with platform-specific code.

* shoes/http: changing the memory allocation situation for http requests. the entire request (except the user data) is free'd by shoes_http_request_free. also changing to more generic naming, in prep for `upload`.

* lib/shoes.rb: only require resolv-replace on windows, where synchronous dns can freeze the app.
 * static/manual.txt: span docs by franois vaux.
* shoes/native: a number of UTF-8 fixes for Windows controls, found by dmitry ustalov. great work!
* shoes/native/windows.c: remove the hscroll styles on windows' edit boxes, to allow wrapping.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: ruby 1.8.6 doesn't include Enumerable#index without params.
* shoes/native/windows.c: check the window class before handling key events. this was causing a crash on alt+tab on windows. (thanks to jesse thompson for seeing this.)
* shoes/http: adds support for downloads from other schemes (such as https.)
* shoes/ruby.c: Background.fill= and Border.fill=, based on seth thomas rasmussen's suggestion.
* shoes/native/gtk.c: nesting the video in a GtkDrawingArea. it's supposed to be lighter.
* shoes/ruby.c: fix vlc options for version 0.8.6.
* shoes/ruby.c: adding some extra vlc options to suppress the window title and quiet down stdout.

* lib/shoes.rb: lacuna is to jaggy on windows at 12px.
 * shoes/canvas.c: no need to have snapshot_nada method.
* bugs/project.yaml: next release is policeman, close raisins.
* shoes/native/gtk.c: only monitor the states of shift, ctrl and alt.
* CHANGELOG: add raisins feature list.
* shoes/canvas.c: call slot mark routine for each canvas. found a crash when the `controls` array was getting free'd.
* shoes/native/windows.c: utf-8 text fixes for the windows clipboard.

* Rakefile: inaugurate the "Policeman" moniker. throw an error if a name is used that's been tagged.
 * lib/shoes.rb: RELEASES constant lists all release names.
* bugs: closing some bugs, moving others to the next release.
* bugs: windows keyboarding troubles for next release.
* shoes/native/gtk.c: had a casting warning on the gtk+ window.
* shoes/ruby.c: use ATTR macro in place of rb_hash_aref, to solve a link problem in samples/good-vjot.rb introduced by an earlier commit.
* shoes/canvas.c: easing some of the flicker i see on link cursors.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: images of all elements.
* static/manual.txt: filling in the intro to the reference section.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: page next links for the built-in manual.
* shoes/native/gtk.c: center new windows, as on the other platforms.
* shoes/ruby.c: fixes to the textblock hover event, to resolve problems with link underlines remaining.
* bugs: last minute raisins issues, many of them related to packaging.
* lib/shoes.rb: new splash window, opening with the modal file dialog was weird.
* bugs: reminder to work on svg support at a later date.
* bugs: resize feature for january.
* bugs/: the `upload` feature.
* bugs/: detailing a few features for murder.
* shoes/ruby.c: bug found by tieg where `left` and `top` report padded values when in nested slots.
* shoes/native/windows.c: on windows, all file-related dialogs should return with normal slashes, since many ruby methods expect it.
* Rakefile: on windows, copy pre-compiled extensions from deps.
* req/*/gemspec: working on getting the gemspecs backward compatible with older deps. (for ed heil and krzysztof)
* platform/msw/base.nsi: add start menu link for the packager.
* shoes/http/nsurl.m: fixed crash with downloader on os x, introduced by premature freeing of memory in commit b716d34.
* bugs/: added two murder features.
* samples/expert-pong.rb: the pong.
* bugs/: adding image :data feature and closing some raisins.
* shoes/ruby.c: proportional scaling of images, if only one dimension is sized. new shoes_element struct, :attach only honors objects that house that struct.
* README: some URL and slight text changes.
* shoes/ruby.c: inside a widget, treat as a top-level canvas.
* shoes/image.c: log an error if an image gives HTTP 4xx, 5xx, etc. thanks, alexander rakoczy!
* samples/expert-definr.rb: doesn't use open-uri any longer.
* lib/shoes/setup.rb: error handling during gem installation, closer to vassilis rizopoulos' patch.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: use COMMONFILES const as suggested by lionel orry.
* lib/shoes/setup.rb: add --ruby flag outside the quotes in Gem.ruby.
* shoes/canvas.c: go with `cairo_fill_extents` on older cairos. (ubuntu 8.04)
* platform/nix/Makefile: left out the interpolation parens.
* platform/nix/Makefile: okay, the backticks needed to go. the shell strings seem to work with the if and filter.
* platform/nix/Makefile: kxxxx, had the makefile syntax wrong. the if was just completely convoluted.
* platform/nix/Makefile: the standard Makefile wasn't handling vlc 0.8 right. thanks, botp!
* platform/mac/pangorc: default to /Volumes/Shoes path, so that fonts will work if launched from the dmg.

* shoes/canvas.c: cast to a float, in the `every` method. this was screwing up the timing of the console repaints. a byproduct of the switch to rb_parse_args.
 * shoes/ruby.c: add floats to rb_parse_args.
* shoes/canvas.c: in :center-style shapes, transformations need to happen around the center point. thanks to ashbb for pointing this out. i went overboard with commit 18b82b1.
* Rakefile: some actions now require rubygems to be loaded.
* Rakefile: delete the `bugs` directory before packaging. include libcurl.so in the linux i686 distro.

* shoes/canvas.c: pass only the final hash to widget's flow.
 * shoes/ruby.c: allow pipe to ignore trailing args.
* shoes/ruby.c: fix rb_parse_args to skip matches with too few args.
* static/manual.txt: splitting into "Introducing" and "Installing" sections.
* shoes/ruby.c: freeze the hash sent back by `style`, requiring all alterations to go through `style` or other methods (such as `hide` and `show`)
* shoes/canvas.c: sort out hide/show for nested fixed and scrolling slots. thanks, krzysztof!
* static/manual.txt: added some tiger and vista screenshots.
* platform/nix/Makefile: support for new core gem installations in the standard makefile.
* platform/nix/Makefile: vlc 0.9 support in the standard makefile.
* platform/nix/INSTALL: in ibex, it's libvlc-dev not libvlc0-dev.
* static/manual.txt: add picture of shoes running on ubuntu.
* samples/expert-funnies.rb: fixed the indexed comic.
* shoes/canvas.c: more accurate mouse off (leave) events.

* shoes/app.c: fix a bug that was ignoring blocks to Shoes.app.
 * shoes/canvas.c: rework arg parsing for canvas manipulation and creation.
* shoes/ruby.c: adding 'e' and 'E' checks to rb_parse_args.
* shoes/app.c: pass a url to `window` or `dialog`.

* shoes/ruby.c: fixes to rb_parse_args (variations on types, match non-nil, empty arg lists, bug in optional args)
 * shoes/canvas.c: continuing work replacing rb_scan_args.

* shoes/ruby.c: replacing rb_scan_args with rb_parse_args throughout Shoes. this func allows many method signatures at once and respects duck typing. like the `image` method has a signature of "ii|h,s|h,|h" -- three possible permutations, the pipe indicates optional args sort of like PyArg_Parse.
* shoes/http/curl.c: fix :body option on `download` for curl.
* shoes/http/winhttp.c: honor custom headers, method, body with winhttp.
Merge commit 'devyn/master'

* shoes/http/nsurl.m: finishing up the setting of headers, request method and request body under os x.
 * Rakefile: vlc 0.8 support on os x.
* shoes/ruby.h: keep the symbol list in a macro, it's too much trouble to keep track of.
Added :align and :justify styles

* req/json: including the json gem by florian frank in the shoes stdlib.
 * Rakefile: some alterations to get all the extensions built and placed.

* Rakefile: installing hpricot and sqlite3 as gems, instead of directly.
 * lib/shoes/cache.rb: setting up the central gems directory, but also allowing hpricot and sqlite3 to be required without loading of rubygems.
 * req/rubygems: updated to 1.3.0.
* static/manual.txt: a few helpful corrections from vitygas. thankkkksy!
* shoes/canvas.c: solving a variety of warnings and problems with different ruby versions.

* shoes/image.c: sha-1 had problems on 64-bit arch due to length of
   the unsigned long.

* shoes/image.c: separate out `shoes_image_downloaded` function, since it's not safe to run this code in a separate thread.
 * shoes/http.h: in HTTP_EVENT, let's allocate fresh event structs, since the static structs could tromp all over each other.

* lib/shoes.rb: allow anonymous classes to become widgets.
 * samples/simple-menu.rb: inherit from Shoes::Widget, it's good form.

* shoes/ruby.c: bug discovered by zulfiqar ali.  shapes using mode
   :center don't get click events in the right coordinates.  i'm glad
   this was found, there was inelegance in the old approach.

* shoes/ruby.c: gradient bug reported by jerry anning.  moved away from
   the overly complicated and problematic matrix transformation and
   opted for graphing the linear gradient along a 2-d space.
* shoes/canvas.h: VIDEO=0 wasn't building on libvlc < 0.8.
* static/manual.txt: docs for the :secret style.
* shoes/ruby.c: it appears that radial gradients need to be offset before painting.  this must be because it isn't tiled like other patterns.

* shoes/canvas.c: slots should copy the pens of their parent stacks when they're created.
 * shoes/ruby.c: use `shoes_pattern_new` rather than `to_pattern` when converting ranges to gradients.
* static/manual.txt: finished the first draft of the style master list, mostly had some text styles left to describe.
* static/manual.txt: filling in a few more text and event styles.

* static/manual.txt: starting a new page in the manual -- the styles master list.
 * shoes/ruby.c: fix play_id warning.
* shoes/ruby.c: free the vlc media player instance.

* shoes/ruby.c: support for VLC 0.9.x.  i'm trying to get both 0.8 and
   0.9 APIs supported simultaneously, so there's going to be some macro
   tricks for a little bit here.
* shoes/ruby.c: check for :state in the control options.
* shoes/ruby.c: separate out the try_state func.
* shoes/native/windows.c: bug in the windows' control state. swap the boolean value.
* shoes/ruby.c: beginning work on `state=` and `state` for setting controls in disabled and read-only modes.

* shoes/native/cocoa.m: wrap all cocoa alterations in an exception handler. this solves the cross-thread EXC_BAD_ACCESS crash.
 * shoes/app.c: no need to remove the timers twice. (it's done in shoes_app_clear already.)
 * lib/shoes/setup.rb: Shoes.visit isn't threadsafe, for some reason.  i think there is some GC screwiness in there.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: embedding the coolvetica font for the manual titles.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: manual scroll jumps were busted since `app.slot` was introduced.
* shoes/ruby.c: fix for video control, removed this line in the warnings cleanup.

* Rakefile: turn on all warnings, solve everything in sight.
 * shoes/ruby.c: of note, a memory leak of PangoAttrLists and no longer ignoring the port number on URLs.

* shoes/image.c: solving warnings on fread, fwrite and the curl calls.
 * shoes/http/curl.c: ditto.
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/why/shoes
add ask_open_folder and ask_save_folder to the manual
* static/manual.txt: a note about the os x font cache.
* shoes/native/cocoa.m: use the autorelease macros to release the font name.
* static/manual.txt: documentation for the Shoes::FONTS constant.
Merge branch 'master' of why@orleans.hobix.com:~/git/shoes
* static/manual.txt: a starting list of what font formats might be supported by which platforms.
* shoes/native/windows.c: filter out dups in the font list on windows.
* shoes/native/cocoa.m: shoes_font_list stalled under os x.
* shoes/native/cocoa.m: working on the font list for os x.

* shoes/native/gtk.c: filter out dups in the font list.

* shoes/world.c: add the current directory to the $LOAD_PATH.  i thought this had been done long ago. :(
* shoes/ruby.c: when arrays are encountered in a textblock, treat them as a collection of text.  means less manual flattening.
* shoes/ruby.c: stroke width for the textblock cursor needed to be at least 1px with the new cairo (given that antialiasing is off)

* shoes/ruby.c: solved crash on the color method_missing if cColors gets changed.  also, alias the constant
 at ALL_NAMED_COLORS so it doesn't go missing.
* lib/shoes/cache.rb: pulse animation on the gem installer.
* lib/shoes/image.rb: refresh the timestamp in the cache if a file is still good.

* lib/shoes/data.rb: the central shoes database, used presently for caching.
 * lib/shoes/image.rb: cache image metadata in the database.
 * req/sqlite3/: keeping the native driver, rather than the DL driver.
* req/: moved rubygems here. added sqlite3 sources.
* samples/simple-mask.rb: animate and add a background.
* shoes/ruby.c: apply displacement coords to textblocks.

* shoes/app.c: in the last checkin, I cut down the amount of cairo buffer surfaces created (in part because cairo was complaining about ref_counts.)  this change adds a surface when the app is initially started (to keep some samples happy).

* shoes/ruby.c: added `displace_top` and `displace_left` for animating elements into their layout positions.
 * samples/expert-othello.rb: move methods into the Othello module.
* shoes/canvas.c: send keypress events to deeper elements.
* Rakefile: fixed an error regarding jpeg.62 when building on OSX.
* Only force pixman-1 linking on OSX.  Linux should pick it up from pkg-config.  And beside, Cairo 1.4.x and 1.5.x should be fine on Linux/BSD.
* shoes/ruby.c: changed the style :sticky to :attach, since sticky means something in wm terms and i don't like an adjective there.

* lib/shoes/image.rb: no longer using etags to check dups.  very soon the on-disk cache will likely have a little database containing etag, uri, host and mtime to help keep track of what images are what.
 * shoes/ruby.c: keep the full uri as the image object's path.
* shoes/canvas.c: applied phlip's patch to add a `snapshot` method for saving a slot to disk as :svg, :ps or :pdf.

* shoes/canvas.c: only create a nested slot if :scroll => true. (considering a :clip => true as well.)
 * shoes/ruby.c: the toplevel nested slot on a class-based Shoes app has :height => 1.0.
 * samples/: update a few samples to use the :height and :scroll styles.
* .gitignore: leave object files, generate files out of this.
* bugs/: closed the cairo/pango issue on osx.

* lib/shoes/help.rb: starting work on an events page.
 * shoes/canvas.c: timing debug info.
* shoes/ruby.c: add file name and line number output to the console.

* rubygems/: update to 1.1.1.
 * shoes/canvas.c: create a fixed scroll window off-screen then it'll be resized during the first paint.  previously, the computation of the window size was off, cause negative heights and such business.

* shoes/ruby.h: wrapping st.h in extern "C" in case we're on a c++ compiler. (msvc's linker wouldn't build things.)
 * shoes/world.h: st_foreach cast on windows.

* shoes/image.c: implementing a in-memory image cache, so files are only hit once.  still need to work on expiring images from the cache.
 * shoes/ruby.c: broken images are a one-pixel blank image.
* lib/shoes.rb: due to the recent move away from TOPLEVEL_BINDING, use caller[0] in the setup routine.  was causing the gem installer to stall at end when reloading the Shoes app.

* lib/shoes.rb: replace my total Object.const_set stupidness with a real Shoes::MAIN object and binding.
 * lib/shoes/cache.rb: get the progress bar hooked into the Gem UI.
* lib/shoes.rb: support the __END__ block on scripts launched by Shoes.  thanks, pedro mg for the suggest.
* bugs/: two issues from phlip - invalid element stylings and text rotation.
* bugs/: converted from monolithic bugs.yaml to bugs/ directory.  well done, wm morgan!
* Rakefile: INSTALL insert was screwing up newlines.

* README: outlining the basic github + rake steps.
 * platform/nix/INSTALL: making the INSTALL steps an insert for the README.
* platform/nix/Makefile: remove the `clean` step from the build process, so `make && make install` won't build twice.  remove the `shoes` step as there is no such file created.
* platform/nix/Makefile: use RUBY_SO_NAME when linking.

* Rakefile: include ruby .h files on osx.

* Rakefile: write out VERSION.txt and include the new shoes shell script with the osx build.

* shoes/app.c: smaller scrollwheel stepping on osx.

* lib/shoes/cache.rb: just pass the app window to the thread, rather than passing as an instance var.

* bugs.yaml: add a few more bugs from trac.

* lib/shoes/cache.rb: give the setup window a relevant title.

* lib/shoes/log.rb: increase the log refresh timer.

* shoes/app.c: expose events at the toplevel window cause way too much repainting.  still need to get invalidated regions working and avoid any other redundant repaints.  also, the gdk process updates really doesn't solve the threading issues.
* shoes/image.c: handle png failure.
* shoes/image.c: graceful failure for jpegs, if the image is invalid.
* shoes/app.c: fix dialog messages to work with changing focus between windows.
* lib/shoes/image.rb: since drive letters are considered a scheme by the URI class, let's only let URI::HTTP and URI::FTP remote load.

* shoes/app.c: use API calls to check the threads, since `curr_thread` and `main_thread` changed names between patchlevels.
 * shoes/ruby.c: App.method_missing uses ts_funcall2, which fabricates a block if none is given.  Calling rb_funcall2 directly if that's the case.  (Caused a bug where all images had a click block and a hover.)

* shoes/ruby.c: adding the Shoes::Widget class.
 * lib/shoes.rb: all Widget subclasses get a lowercased method on the app.
* shoes/ruby.c: allow negative widths, they're in NKS.
* shoes/canvas.c: firing the `start` event after the first paint.

* shoes/ruby.c: fundamental-- negative values for coordinates should be negative coordinates. previously, they wrapped around the canvas. but we have :left and :right for changing the origin of an element.
* lib/shoes/cache.rb: continuing work on the gem setup routines.
* shoes/canvas.c: introducing `start` and `finish` which are sort of like html's `load` and `unload`.
* shoes/ruby.c: ever since i started computing the layout before painting it, the CHANGED_COORDS() test no longer applies.
* shoes/ruby.c: $0 pointer was going out of scope.

* shoes/app.c: App#started? returns true if the window is fully loaded.
 * lib/shoes.rb: Shoes.setup for easing the installation of gem prerequisites.

* shoes/ruby.c: set up $0.
 * lib/shoes.rb: with each loaded script, set $0 and __FILE__.
 * samples/irb.rb: set __FILE__ and __LINE__.
* shoes/ruby.c: simplifying text flowing.  as with elements: largest font wins.  still need to get all text to match a common baseline.
* shoes/world.c: have sigint leave the gtk main loop.
* shoes/app.c: going back to the rb_thread_select loop and calling `gdk_window_process_all_updates` directly if we're not in the main thread.  much better really.

* shoes/app.c: using g_source_attach rather than hooking the main loop.  i know it's more expensive this way, but the other way just simply wouldn't fire repaints.  when we move to ruby 1.9, i'll use rb_thread_blocking_region instead.

* shoes/ruby.c: starting to address the flow problems described in ticket #99.  removed marginy from shoes_canvas and starting to use the max endy.  so the rules are: margins no longer overlap and biggest element wins.

 * shoes/app.c: the shoes_slot_win32proc for handling all the window messages for the above.

* shoes/canvas.c: fixes for backgrounds and borders on the toplevel slot, which were zero width due to a change i made earlier with regard to nested slots.  the toplevel slot now reinforces its width in shoes_place.

* shoes/app.c: get edit_box and edit_line change events hooked up on windows.
 * shoes/ruby.c: the ES_MULTILINE style must be used on both edit controls, otherwise WM_SETTEXT spews some wretched infinite recursive.
* shoes/ruby.c: edit_box on win32 was neither multiline nor present day.
* shoes/ruby.c: gtk def outside of preprocessor if.

* shoes/ruby.c: the `changed` signal for edit_line and edit_box.
 * samples/jot.rb: sort of a clone of chris wanstrath's vjot.

* shoes/canvas.c: long overdue patches to allow any element's `draw` method to simply compute its position rather than completely draw it.  also, many positioning and layout issues with nested fixed-height boxes.  such boxes get drawn by os paint calls so they often get drawn much later on.  now their coordinates are computed in advance of drawing.  added FLAG_ORIGIN for the shoes_place struct, which indicates that an element's contents have their origin reset, but the element itself abides by its parent's translation.
* shoes/ruby.c: ditto.

* shoes/ruby.c: use GTK_WIDGET_HAS_FOCUS, gtk-based shoes wasn't building.
* Rakefile: only add the -g compile flag if DEBUG var is set.  for both fixes, thankyou MenTaLguY.

* shoes/app.c: removing unneeded hit test and control click event code.
* shoes/ruby.c: fixing shoes_control_focus on osx.  tabbing is still not happening, however.

* shoes/app.c: handle the WM_SETFOCUS and WM_ACTIVATE messages, to get the tab and enter keys to work within a form.  see ticket #15, thanks garrett!
* shoes/ruby.c: shoes_control_focus for cross-platform keyboard focusing.

* shoes/ruby.c: changes for ListBox#items= caused compilation errors, got it working with MenuRef.
* Rakefile: add the `samples` to the root of the dmg installer, slight change of background.
* samples/clock.rb: oh no, left out the clock.  thanks, deejay.
* shoes/app.c: if no file is selection in the open dialog, just quit.
* samples/clock.rb: shoes clock by thomas bell, very much thanks
* shoes/ruby.c: added ListBox#items and ListBox#items=.
* Rakefile: place the source tarball in pkg/ with everything else.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: a batch file in Common Files\Shoes runs the latest installed Shoes.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: changing the right arrow to a pointy quote for the time being.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: expanding the art section to describe `line` and `arrow` and `stroke` and so on.  added return values everything that was already there.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: ease up on the licensing jargon.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: adding license page to the windows installer.
* shoes/app.c: kxxx, i need you shoes/dialog.h.
* shoes/app.c: moving the NoScript proc into shoes_app_visit, so if no script is given, the open file dialog is thrown.

* shoes/canvas.c: double-painting until i can come up with a better shoes_canvas_compute.
* shoes/app.c: send a single motion event on initial paint.
* shoes/canvas.c: initial stab at a `window` method.

* shoes/app.c: width and height were swapped on r322.
* shoes/world.c: handle running shoes without parameters under r321.
* shoes/app.c: window resizing on osx.
* shoes/world.c: simplified the shoes_load() and shoes_start() code to ease loading of scripts into new windows during execution.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: filling in `oval` and `rect` docs, changing the layout of list items.
* lib/shoes.rb: wrong load order for shoes/cache and shoes/help.
* samples/definr.rb: dictionary lookup sample which illustrates use of threads.

* shoes/app.c: working on kAEOpenDocuments support so you can double-click on shoes scripts.
* Rakefile: dmg installer for osx.
* platform/mac/Info.plist: associate with shy.
* platform/mac/: assorted dmg-related additions, including mozilla's handy pkg-dmg.
* COPYING: narrowed to fit the installer popup.

* samples/form.shy: updated shy example.
* lib/shoes.rb: allow shoes.rb to be required from ruby in a limited form.

* shoes/app.h: default window size is 500x700.
* Rakefile: removal of .svn directories.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: installs to Common Files\Shoes\0.rNNN.
* lib/shoes.rb: use --manual rather than --help.

* shoes/app.c: working on VS6 support.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: continuing to improve installer, reducing size, appearance.
* platform/msw/base.nsi: working on the installer.

* shoes/ruby.c: special handling of REL_TILE position elements (background and border) to ensure that they don't follow the cursor.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: no need to absolutely position the background.
* shoes/ruby.c: a bit more efficent storage of placement settings, working on multiple background placement.
* shoes/ruby.c: in flows the canvas's left hand side wasn't being acknowledged, which caused some elements to wrap prematurely.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: messing with a fade in the help title.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: preserve leading spaces in the code samples.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: playing with the spacing and layout of the manual.

* shoes/ruby.c: working on text margins, to make them work more like HTML.  if `nil` then use the text height to make `auto` margins.  and use the greater of two margins that meet.
* shoes/canvas.c: add `marginy` for tracking the current cursor's margin.
* use-deps: let's try using DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH here and unsetting it in the shoes shell script.

* shoes/dialogs.c: the `ask_color` dialog should return a Color object rather than a color string.
* shoes/ruby.c: added the `SHOES_COLOR_OPAQUE` def.
* shoes/ruby.c: using Data_Wrap_Struct rather than Data_Make_Struct, since the GC allocated structs were getting free'd early on certain win32, especially vista.
* Rakefile: be sure DEBUG build includes debugging symbols on win32.
* use-deps: switching to DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH, given ed heil's travails.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: styles for titles, code backgrounds.

* lib/shoes/inspect.rb: use Hackety Hack's style of inspection.
* lib/shoes/help.rb: manual layout borrowed from Hackety Hack.
* shoes/app.c: use the sunken window edge on win32.
* samples/book.rb: yeah, those paragraphs should be in a stack.

* shoes/app.c: add osx handler for list_box change event.
* shoes/ruby.c: button now has a `click` method and list_box has a `change` method.

* shoes/app.c: win32 list_box change event.
* shoes/ruby.c: gtk list_box change event.

* lib/shoes/cache.rb: working on auto-installation of missing gems and script caching in ~/.shoes.
* rubygems/: using svn:external to fetch from rubyforge http.
* shoes/ruby.c: evening out the layout of long paragraphs in stacks and flows.
* shoes/ruby.c: an `exit` method for departing the app.
* lib/shoes.rb: playing around with at-symbol prefix on shoes url syntax.
* shoes/canvas.c: open and close the line path, good thanks to thomas bell.
* shoes/ruby.c: slightly pad the height of buttons on osx.
* shoes/ruby.c: font sizes default to pixels, to make font sizes more uniform across platforms.
* samples/irb.rb: MimickIRB::Empty error on osx.
* lib/shoes.rb: @localhost on the commandline is an alias for http://localhost:53045/.
* shoes/ruby.c: moving all `style` and `move` methods into generic macros.
* shoes/ruby.c: the `style` method for text blocks, images, etc.
* shoes/ruby.c: `move` method for native controls, text blocks and video.
* lib/shoes.rb: the `width` and `height` should be passed on to the canvas, not to the styles.
* shoes/ruby.c: Image.path= and Image.path, thanks ed heil!
* shoes/ruby.c: now these image events are full of personality.
* shoes/canvas.c: allow events to be set to `nil` to clear them.
* lib/shoes.rb: use `para` rather than `text`.  thanks, Jonty and DJ!

* shoes/ruby.c: Shoes::Shape has replaced Shoes::Path.
* shoes/canvas.c: likewise, `shape` method has replaced `path`.
* shoes/ruby.c: added `show`, `hide` and `toggle` for text blocks, images, shapes and patterns.

* shoes/app.c: add a default LinkHover style.
* shoes/ruby.c: trigger repaints on hover and leave.  keep a count of changed elements within a given canvas.
* shoes/ruby.c: fixed up click, hover and leave events for links.  the :url setting is no more as well, since :click is sufficient.
* samples/irb.rb: a shoes wrapper around IRB, to be used in Hackety Hack.

* Rakefile: okay, libungif it is on osx.
* samples/video.rb: that youtube link expired.
* Rakefile: use r1 as svn revision if building on a platform without subversion.
* Rakefile: rake tarball task.
* Makefile: print option summary rather than complete CFLAGS and LDFLAGS.

* INSTALL: instructions for the source tarball.
* Makefile: add VIDEO and DEBUG options.
* Rakefile: don't call install_name_tool on win32 or linux.

* Rakefile: copy plugins from the deps/lib/vlc directory.
* samples/video.rb: use an FLV as the sample, since it's such a predominant format.

* Rakefile: the output Shoes.app now gets all the VLC libs and plugins, then the dylibs get stripped, ready to tarball.
* shoes/ruby.c: hurray, finally video is working under OSX, had to fiddle with setting the viewport and clipping region for awhile, but yeah.

* Rakefile: working on VIDEO options for osx.
* use-deps: updated to reflect most recent deps for osx.

* Rakefile: added a PPC env var for cross-compiling on Intel macs.
* shoes/app.c: use a UInt32 for 10.3 support.
* Rakefile: use giflib rather than libungif, see #47.  thanks, arcum42!
* shoes/app.c: use SB_THUMBTRACK to smoothly scroll the window when the thumb is dragged.
* shoes/ruby.c: improving text layout, wit special regard to #48.

* shoes/app.c: use WS_CLIPCHILDREN to be sure the list box gets drawn.
* shoes/canvas.c: reselect the DC's original bitmap, for good measure.
* shoes/app.c: going back to Thread.sleep rather than rb_thread_schedule, which was eating up lots of cpu.
* shoes/ruby.c: taking line spacing into account when laying out text with other elements.

* Rakefile: new UNIVERSAL option for building an i386/ppc fat binary.  will probably change to using lipo directly.
* platform/mac: slight changes to get Shoes.app to work when double-clicked.
* shoes/app.c: here, let's use rb_thread_schedule instead.
* shoes/app.c: altered the win32 event loop to spend some sleep time in ruby, to let threads run.  thanks to bb in #shoes for tracking this down!
* shoes/canvas.c: i can't believe it, harold was right about free-ing the bitmap, now everything's so much more solid on win32.
* shoes/ruby.c: in stacks, the canvas x-cursor needs to be reset to the x-most position rather than zero.
* Rakefile: amd64 fix from bronson (#20) oh good
* shoes/canvas.c: win32 scroll fixes (ticket #42); scroll height should default to 1 pixel below canvas size.

* shoes/ruby.c: ListBox.choose for OS X.
* shoes/app.c: browser launching for OS X.
* Rakefile: further work on the VIDEO build, in the form of preprocessor defs and gcc flags.

* Rakefile: video support disabled by default; use `rake VIDEO=true` to build it.
* shoes/: defines to make the above possible.  NotImplementedError returned if `video` method is called.

* shoes/canvas.c: give the default white background to the top-level canvas only, we want the nested canvases to be transparent.
* shoes/ruby.c: bug in text placement, turns out the indent doesn't need to be converted to pixels using PANGO_SCALE.
* Makefile: add vlc dependency, just run `ruby -v` to have things abort if Ruby's not found.

* shoes/app.c: browser launching on win32.
* shoes/ruby.c: choosing from the list_box on win32.

* shoes/canvas.c: the Canvas.style method can be used to alter page styles (from pg 38 of Nobody Knows Shoes)
* shoes/app.c: http links spawn a web browser (from pg 37 of Nobody Knows Shoes)
* shoes/ruby.c: `choose` option and method for selecting an item in the list_box.  incomplete on win32 and osx.
* shoes/canvas.c: create stacks and flows without a block.

* shoes/canvas.c: send the element clicked as the block var to a click block.
* shoes/app.c: `inscription` is smaller than `para`.
* shoes/ruby.c: adding a `parent` method to all elements.

* shoes/canvas.c: fixing height of scrolling panes.
* shoes/ruby.c: methods for styling text.
* lib/shoes.rb: newer builds use `visit` rather than `goto`.
* shoes/ruby.c: what the datsun? cVideo was descended from cImage, i am a disaster.

* shoes/canvas.c: pass `motion` and `click` events to images.
* shoes/ruby.c: figure out coordinates of images for the above events.
* shoes/canvas.c: a very bad bug in updating box heights, was trying to apply this operation to paths and text and just whatever was lying around.

* shoes/canvas.c: scrolly now accompanies each slot.  and each slot is recopied on redraw.
* shoes/ruby.c: native controls and movie windows should now cooperate with the scrollbar.
* shoes/config.h: minor semicolon debacle.

* shoes/ruby.c: remove redundant placement code and get video and PLACE_CONTROL to cooperate under gtk.
* shoes/canvas.c: slight casting issue with hide and show for native controls.

* shoes/app.c: create a window class for the video hwnd.
* shoes/ruby.c: get the vlc control working on win32, mirror the functionality of other native controls, flesh out show and hide.
* Rakefile: win32 linking for vlc.

* shoes/ruby.c: text in a stack was starting at 0px left.  boo.
* samples/book.rb: use text in a stack for the titles.

* shoes/canvas.c: fixes to tracking of canvas height.  canvases in a row all receive the same background height. and gave links back the block. (see use of links in samples/video.rb.)
* shoes/canvas.h: the topy tracks the top position of each canvas, before margins and padding (which effects place.y)
* shoes/ruby.c: video methods `play`, `pause`, `stop` and so.  also, fixes to text going to the edge of the right-hand of the screen.
* shoes/ruby.c: for a password field, pass `:secret => true` into `edit_line`.  thankyou, ardekantur!
* shoes/ruby.c: embedded VideoLAN and added the `video` method for laying it out.  only GTK has been implemented presently.
* shoes/ruby.h: changing `goto` to `visit`.
* Makefile: getting the `install` task to put everything in /usr/local/lib/shoes.
* shoes/internal.h: `min` and `max` macros, rather than the ternary.
* shoes/ruby.c: allow string percentages and pixel widths.  the color method_missing on App.
* shoes/ruby.c: casting to PangoWeight to shut up win32.
* shoes/canvas.c: working on scrolling stacks on osx.

* shoes/ruby.c: a few bugs in text styling.  certain hash attrs were being ignored, either because the style_of function was returning prematurely or because of the order of things in the PangoAttrList.  also displaying the alpha as a float in Color.to_s.

* shoes/ruby.c: new `leading` style for controlling pixel spaces between lines in a paragraph.
* samples/book.rb: example use of leading.

* shoes/canvas.c: added `sup` and `sub` elements.
* shoes/ruby.c: added `variant`, `rise` and `kerning` styles.  also, `size` can receive friendly stuff like `x-small` and `large`.

* shoes/canvas.c: changed `strike` to `del`.
* shoes/ruby.c: supporting `strikecolor` and `undercolor` styles.  also, `family` and `size` styles were swapped and wrong.
* shoes/ruby.c: strikethrough styles, and the `strike` element.

* shoes/ruby.c: fixing links, the shoes_block.links member had to be filled up.
* shoes/canvas.c: links are inside cTextBlock, not cTextClass anymore.
* shoes/ruby.c: add `children` method to all containers.

* shoes/ruby.c: adding a `span` inline, which does just like HTML, for applying adhoc styles.
* samples/: updating some samples with the new methods, still needs lots of work obviously.
* shoes/canvas.c: various text block styles `banner`, `title`, `subtitle`, `tagline`, `caption`, `inscription`.

* shoes/canvas.c: added `em`, `link`, `code` and `ins` methods, along with their styles.
* shoes/ruby.c: getting more sophisticated with the style support... all types of underlines, weights, font families, font descriptions.  styles can be customized at each individual fragment.

* shoes/canvas.c: added `strong` method, macros for INLINE and BLOCK markup.
* shoes/ruby.c: first stab at adding pango attributes during iteration.

* shoes/ruby.c: get Para.to_s and Para.replace working.  the new Shoes::Text class, for inline text fragments.
* lib/shoes.rb: removing old text helpers, they'll reappear as subclasses of Shoes::TextBlock.
* shoes/ruby.c: rewriting all of the text classes, getting rid of HTML support.  i'd rather have everything be totally Ruby and then we can convert various markups to that.
* shoes/internal.c: use _vsnprintf instead of _vsnprintf_s, no need to truncate.
* shoes/world.c: use shoes_snprintf instead of sprintf to prevent buffer overflow.  thanks harold you snatchy old cat youuu!!

* shoes/ruby.c: ahh, ended up needing App.method_missing for anything that ends up getting added to Canvas or Shoes classes at runtime.  perhaps could use method_added in the future.  this gave me a chance to wrap up ts_funcall2 which means Shoes actually has a hack by the wonderful Guy Decoux!
* samples/mask.rb: using `title` now that the above is fixed.

* Rakefile: include pango modules in the distro, was throwing warnings for ticker #29.
* samples/mask.rb: the mask sample from hackety.org.

* shoes/canvas.c: once a url is handled by a click, dispose of it (see ticket #34.) also, some absent marking on Canvas.
* shoes/ruby.c: no need to release GTK widgets, seems GTK does that automatically and can cause widgets to disappear prematurely. thanks, harkins!!
* Makefile: slimmer source tarballs.

* shoes/app.c: done implementing the main scroll view on win32.
* shoes/canvas.c: scroll the canvas on bitblt.  hopefully soon i can come back to this and cache the last bitmap then just redraw the invalidated regions.
* Makefile: okay, the Makefile is building shoes-bin and libshoes.so.
* Makefile: still working on the shoes shell wrapper.

* Makefile: standard Makefile for Linux/BSD distros.
* COPYING: the mit license.
* shoes/ruby.c: using HOOK cast to keep call_cfunc portable.
* shoes/canvas.c: moved win32 scrollbar calculations alongside the other platforms.
* shoes/app.c: okay, starting work on scrollbars in win32.
* shoes/ruby.c: using CASTHOOK to solve win32 casting compiler errors.
* shoes/canvas.c: reset the cursor on a scrollable stack or flow.

* shoes/canvas.c: the `cy` (cursor y-pos) shouldn't be moved on a parent canvas unless the `cx` has overflowed.  i'm not even going to try to complicate the y-cursor on a flow.  it shouldn't try to fill in all available y-space.  the designer can go ahead and use stacks-in-flows to do that.
* samples/book.rb: line things up a bit nicer.
* shoes/ruby.c: getting closer with text layout intersperse with controls and images.
* shoes/ruby.c: improved text layout in both flows and stacks.

* shoes/ruby.c: only allow top-level canvases to honor the nesting.  i may need to move the shoes_canvas_c_* methods into cShoes, something to consider.
* shoes/app.c: always push the App or Shoes-descendant class on to the nesting array first.

* shoes/ruby.c: hooray, using call_cfunc from eval.c, both Canvas and App now respect the new canvas nesting.
* shoes/app.c: be sure the nesting array is cleared if an exception is thrown.
* shoes/ruby.h: the complete list of Canvas/App shared methods is stored here now.
* shoes: minor fixes throughout to use the new os x structs.

* shoes/app.c: okay, Shoes is at least building on win32 again.  an important fix to get Shoes away from reliance on global_app.  the app pointer is now attached to the window handle as GWL_USERDATA.
* shoes/config.h: key events happen at the window level, but the HINSTANCE is kept at the world level.

* shoes/world.c: introduced the new shoes_world_t struct so I can start to implement multiple windows soon.
* shoes/app.c: the shoes_app struct is now wrapped by the App class.
* shoes/ruby.c: heavy reorganization of how blocks are called.  prevalent use of `instance_eval` has been abandoned in favor of evaluation at the app-level and tracking of canvas nesting.  i just think instance_eval was too confusing for beginners, I'm much happier with this.  In this way, instance variables can be used to store elements rather than plain variables.
* samples/: use of instance variables to store controls and changes to reflect the new scoping.  this revision breaks a lot of old code and doesn't yet compile on osx and win32.

* shoes/ruby.c: errors thrown from `method_missing` for creating colors was all whack.  it's now displayed just like Ruby's own method_missing.  thanks to Garrett Buell for his script which revealed this issue!
* use-deps: sorry that LD_LIBRARY_PATH is needed for Ruby presently.
* shoes/app.c: non-resizable windows were way to stripped down on windows.  thanks, deejay.
* Rakefile: slight fix for compiling with ddk.
* Rakefile: build was broken for vs.net 2003.

* Rakefile: okay, linking to jpeg62 on OSX since there's a libJPEG conflict.  also, bin/main.o is supposed to go in shoes-bin.
* lib/shoes.rb: when calling shoes from `open` on OSX, it passes in a weird commandline arg that was screwin things up.
* Rakefile: oh, brilliant, got Shoes to build using the Windows DDK, this is going to be the recommended approach!
* Rakefile: some kinda hacky stuff to get universal binaries building on osx.

* platform/mac/build-deps.sh: this is the build-gtk.sh script from Inkscape which will build a universal binary for GTK.  we're not going to build all of GTK, I'm just going to hack this script to give us cairo, pango and ruby.  see, i do care about powerpc.
* platform/skel.rb: okay, APPNAME and APPARGS are working on win32.
* Rakefile: more work getting APPNAME and APPARGS moving on OSX.

* bin/main.skel: this file is now preprocessed by rake.  so you can alter the build slightly.  for example, to wrap `sample/follow.rb` in follow.exe, you'd run `rake APPNAME=follow APPARGS=sample/follow.rb`.
* Rakefile: transitioning to a preprocessed bin/main.c.  things are going to broken for a bit.

* shoes/app.c: added `:resizable` option to make a window fixed in size.
* samples/calc.rb: demonstrate the fixed size.

* shoes/canvas.c: working on getting scrollboxes to layout like any other canvas on gtk.
* shoes/app.c: let the gtk idle timer run ruby threads.
* shoes/dialogs.c: open and save dialogs were changing the working directory.  solves #25.
* shoes/app.c: only reg app->slot.controls with GC if on osx or win32.

* shoes/app.c: aha!! the mac and windows crashes for follow.rb were due to app->slot.controls being GC'd.  i think i need to wrap global_app in a Ruby obj at some point.  i believe this takes care of #27, #26 and #10.
* Rakefile: use -lungif, to help #28.
* shoes/canvas.c: scrolling overflow stacks and flows, getting them going on GTK, ensuring expose events get passed down to them and through them.

* shoes/canvas.c: working on show/hide to cooperate with native controls.
* shoes/ruby.c: methods `shoes_control_hide` and `shoes_control_show`.
* Rakefile: when using APPNAME, let's still call the shared `libshoes`.
* samples/calc.rb: fiddling with the background and layout a bit.
* lib/shoes.rb: fix for bad URIs on win32.

* shoes/canvas.c: clear contents array when a canvas is cleared.
* shoes/canvas.h: declare `shoes_linktext_new` for win32. (thanks, garret!)
* shoes/app.c: getting rid of unused title CFStrings.

issue.title: Hi! I cleaned up your code for you!
issue.body:
Hi there!

This is WhitespaceBot. I'm an [open-source](https://github.com/Gunio/LightWrite) robot that removes trailing white space in your code, and gives you a gitignore file if you didn't have one!  

Why whitespace? Whitespace is an eyesore for developers who use text editors with dark themes. It's not  a huge deal, but it's a bit annoying if you use Vim in a terminal. Really, I'm just a proof of  concept - GitHub's V3 API allows robots to automatically improve open source projects, and that's really cool. Hopefully, somebody, maybe you!, will fork me and make me even more useful. My owner is [funding a bounty](http://gun.io/open/12/add-security-flaw-fixing-features-to-whitespacebot) to anybody who can add security fixing features to me. 

I've only cleaned your most popular project, and I've added you to a list of users not to contact again, so you won't get any more pull requests from me unless you ask. If I'm misbehaving, please email my owner and tell him to turn me off! If this is pull request is of no use to you, please just ignore it.

Thanks!
WhiteSpacebot from [Gun.io](http://gun.io).

[6830] Implement custom exit codes on server shutdown/restart

Added the possibility to use custom process return values
instead of hardcoded 0 (shutdown) or 2 (restart) to allow using them
for various custom external features / better handling.

This can be used through 4 commands in ".server" family:
 - shutdown
 - restart
 - idleshutdown
 - idlerestart

Those have from now on 2 arguments, where the second (return value)
is optional:

.server <command> <time> [return_value]

If return_value is not specified, default value (0 or 2) is used.

name: rollo
description: Another Ruby live-MIDI music generator to try out new ideas on

commit.message: using Arkx clock and LiveMIDI extensions to MIDIator, modified to tick at the MIDI Sync/clock level.  Got rid of circular PianoRoll linked list.  Now there's just one PianoRoll which knows about its next degree/chord before-hand.  Using Arkx style scheduling of generate_beats. added :arpeg and :next_arpeg improv
more testing
trying different timer things, working in the test_queue folder.

fixed a bug where if 2 notes were intended to play at the same step, but one of them was on a different channel, they would be played one after another, rather than simultaneously.  The smallest unit of sequencing is now the midi sync, not the step.  I'm trying to make the tempo adjustable on the fly and also allow for different steps per measure.  For example, a TR-909 is 16 steps per measure.  Too keep things simple for now, I'm only using 4 in Rollo.  For the most part, MIDI sync seems to be working, but it's not usable.  There are some times when it seems that the timer waits too long to spit out the MIDI, and emits some hasty notes to compensate for the delay.
README now links to a screencast demo
improvs now have a :channel attribute.  defaults to 0, you can live edit and reroute the channels for an improv in improvs.rb
added sample mp3

improv[:lead] (or any of them) can now be used repeatedly as long as the :name attribute is unique when calling it.  timer_test/without_measures is now the base top-level version, the old is in the save/ folder

timer_test/without_meashures: fixing the memory leak was just a matter of making 2 piano rolls and have their nexts point to each other.  with a little juggling of state, it works nice.  have yet to confirm this on Windows, but it's behaving well on OSX.  the timing seems more stable now after many different @timer.at experiments.  still have problems getting tempos to change in real time

more testing with MIDIator::Timer and time issues.  also my math was wrong with beats/steps/measures/tempo.  experimenting with taking out the 1..4 measures because that was cheating on my part.  the linked list is supposed to provide measure 2 through it's next.  Todays 2 new versions in the timer_test branch also leak memory.. yay.
messing around with the MIDIator::Timer and also sending MIDI Sync

I decided to give the :lead lambda a :simult option.  What really seems to work nice is that when simult == 1, the lambda can pick any note from the scale, because that would be melody like.  However, if simult > 1, those simultaneous notes have a further constraint that they must also be members of the current chord, which is a subset of the current scale.  This prevents ugly chords from taking shape yet permits  the lead lambda to step out of the one-note box, which can get boring.  Not that there's anything wrong with dissonance, we can make room for those improv lambdas too

improvs can be restricted to play within certain bands of the piano roll via the :pov range.  Also the piano roll player creating the MIDI can also be constained to only pay attention to a certain range of notes, ignoring the rest.  see options.rb and improvs.rb. The :lead improv just plays one note at a time.  The :clash improv sounds SPOOKY on purpose.
random changes

Draft implementation of a pure net/ssh actor for command delivery to remote hosts, providing
role definitions and supporting either a direct or gateway based SSH connection.

Current delivery sprinkle script configuration:

  delivery :ssh do

    # defines what hosts relate to what roles, can be a single name or an array per role
    roles   :app => %w( sprinkle.redartisan.com, .... ), :db => ....

    # optional, defines a gateway to send all SSH connections through, defaults to direct
    gateway :host => 'gateway.redartisan.com'

    # optional, SSH user to connect to the gateway and remote host as, defaults to root
    user    'root'
  end

Direct SSH connection successfully tested, spec updates to validate pending.

Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/mitchellh/sprinkle into mitchellh/master

* 'master' of git://github.com/mitchellh/sprinkle:
  Added has_gem verifier which verifiers a ruby gem is installed. An optional version parameter allows you to check for a specific version. Specs and RDoc included.
Added has_gem verifier which verifiers a ruby gem is installed. An optional version parameter allows you to check for a specific version. Specs and RDoc included.

* Added option? to configurable module to allow for methods defined in the options not to be reflected up the method chain
* Added option?(:repository) to gem such that it does not interfere with the installer deployment method
Added some example packages. All of them have been tested personally and work. Also added ruby specific verifiers.
Fixed has_executable with global executables. It wasn't running the command properly.Specs included.
Removed merb from manifest and gemspec.
Pushing a 0.1.6 version of the mitchellh-sprinkle gem.
Removed merb example because it really didn't do anything. Preparing to add a suite of example packages.
Added the 'has_process' verifier. Specs and RDoc covered.
Full RDoc coverage! Sprinkle::Package, Sprinkle::Policy, Sprinkle::Verify and all the built-in verifiers have been documented.
Documented Sprinkle::Script.

I've started documenting all the classes in Sprinkle so that its a little bit easier to approach. I made it to the installers before I realized I had to go to bed. Will finish the other half tomorrow! Run rake docs to generate and view the docs so far.
Remove README.rdoc for README.txt for the sake of doc generation. (rake docs)

* Added specs for pre/post commands added as arrays
* Added procs to be able to be used as pre/post commands
* Added specs for proces on the pre/post commands
Verifiers can be dynamically registered now so sprinkle scripts can define their own verifiers. Specs included.

Added the has_executable verifier. Checks if an executable exists. If no forward slashes are in the argument, it checks to see if the executable is in the global PATH variable. ex: has_executable 'rails'
Added a has_symlink verification. Usage: has_symlink symlink_file[, real_file]. It checks if symlink_file exists andif real_file is given, it checks to see if the symlink points to that file.
Fixed where the pre-verification message was not showing up properly. Specs cover the fix.
Added better logging for verifications both on the debug side and on the normal info side.
Updated gemspec to include new files.
Make the verification logger message include the description of the verify block.
A nice message is displayed notifying the user a package has already been installed and that sprinke is skipping it if this occurs.

When a verification fails, the VerificationFailed exception is raised. Verifications are ran BEFORE a package is installed to check if it has already been installed. If so, it skips. The -f flag has been introduced to force the installation regardless of whether the pre-verification is successful.
A slight change to actors so command statuses can be returned. Does not break anything since its a new optional parameter rather than required. And specs back up capistrano.

A new 'verify' block may be put in a package to verify an installation was successful. A very small example is in the README. Currently a verify block may check for a file or directory, and if the verification fails, the sprinkle script ends gracefully.
Abstracted out specs and changed name of 'Runnable' to 'Configurable' since that makes a lot more sense.
Abstracted out aspects of installer which made it configurable to prepare for verify blocks. Specs all pass.
Intro was somehow deleted when I raked the gem. Seems okay.

Add support for a customized build directory within the source based installer for cases when source archives contain a directory name that doesn't match the primary name of the tar/zip archive. Update specs to validate. Update version to 0.1.5

Move understanding of the package, policy and deployment DSL constructs directly into Object, rather than on Script. This is necessary because embedded sprinkle scripts that use 'require' will fail without it, as Ruby's 'require' implemenentation sets self to be main:Object always, which yields in method not found errors if the DSL methods are only known within instances of Script.

Added support to emulate the OracleAdapter. This is useful when trying to get rails tests to pass since there are still conditionals in the code that check for the current adapter being :OracleAdapter. It emulates the OracleAdapter in the sense that its class is that of the OracleAdapter. This is only turned on for a connection that defines :emulate_oracle_adapter => true during connection establishment.

issue.title: Add a Gitter chat badge to README.md
issue.body:
### Saisse/ci_reporter now has a Chat Room on Gitter

@Saisse has just created a chat room. You can visit it here: [https://gitter.im/Saisse/ci_reporter](https://gitter.im/Saisse/ci_reporter?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&content=body_link).

This pull-request adds this badge to your README.md:

[![Gitter](https://badges.gitter.im/Join Chat.svg)](https://gitter.im/Saisse/ci_reporter?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=body_badge)

Happy chatting.

PS: [Click here](https://gitter.im/settings/badger/opt-out) if you would prefer not to receive automatic pull-requests from Gitter in future.

name: django-comment-utils
description: A fork of James Bennett's django-comment-utils that should work with Django 1.0

commit.message: Added email template

Corrected the signals section to use post_save in the appropriate place.

Also added site to the email context
Modified documentation after pre-1.0 removal
Support for Django 1.0 comments, removed template tags since they are included in Django now
Added management command in a backwards compatible way
patched template tag
trying to fix django 1.0

Fixed #35: Update to deal with signal refactor

name: dm-is-commentable
description: A DataMapper plugin that adds the ability to comment any model.

commit.message:
Object.full_const_get also handles classes nested in modules.

Signed-off-by: Piotr Sarnacki <drogus@gmail.com>
Ability to add blog style comments (name, email, site) as anonymous user
Add blog_style_comments option which adds name, site and email properties
Added some properties to make 'blog style' comments possible
Instance method commentable_class which returns class of commentable (i'm using it often and thought that Kernel.get_const on commentable_class_name in multiple could be moved to model)
Make dm-is-commentable dm-more 0.9.7 compliant.
Added tasks/hoe.rb to get the gem built.
README cosmetics.
Added some motivational background to README
Use fully qualified identifiers when necessary!
Don't use fully qualified names if not necessary.

Use bang! methods where appropriate. Updated documentation.

All enable/disable methods have changed to enable!/disable!
I think this is appropriate since they throw exceptions in
case something goes wrong.
Allow to pass conditions into the :user_comments method.

Removed unnecessary public API.

The 'commentable_fk' and 'comment_remixable' class level
readers were removed because they really seem quite
unnecessary. Specs pass without changes (except for
removing the specs for these very methods).
Allow comment ratings by using dm-is-rateable.
Increased spec coverage to 99%.
Bumped dependencies to '>=0.9.5'.
Updated README.

Simplified implementation and better specs.

Don't rely on too many options for is :commentable.
Instead, use DataMapper property presence to decide
on which was previously decided via different options
to is :commentable. This ideally makes usage of
dm-is-commentable more consistent with what seems
to be a DataMapper convention: List all model properties
within the class body instead of automagically creating
them. This makes perfect sense to me, be it a convention
or not.
Updated README
Push it

name: ljdump
description: Livejournal archive utility

commit.message: update to version 1.5.1
additional information on fetch exception
Don't attempt to fetch a default userpic if the user hasn't set one.

The md5 module is deprecated in favor of the hashlib module in newer Python
versions.

i'm an idiot and forgot to blow away the variable declarations inside
replaceLJTags after moving them to the global scope.

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

changed the way i replace the lj-user tags;  lj usernames allow underscores,
domains do not.  Rather that converting the underscores to hyphens, I used
the alternate URL scheme supported by LJ

disabled the lj-embed code until i can figure out how to make it actually
work

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

Moved the "lj tag" regular expression objects to the global scope (so they
don't need to be recompiled on each iteration).  --suggestion by jparise

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

now replace lj comm as well as lj-cut tags

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

added regex to replace "lj user" tags with normal links.
links are set to class='lj-user' too allow for potential css manipulation in
the future

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

Add vim modeline for ljdump.py

ljdump.py is written with expanded (i.e. spaces for tabs) 4-space tabs,
which isn't the same as everyone's (certianly not my) default settings.
This patch adds a vim modeline to the end of the file to force a change in
settings for this file

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>

Handle weird comment retrieval permissions case

Saw the error

Fetching journal entries for: palfrey
Fetching journal entry L-867 (create)
Fetching journal comments for: palfrey
*** Error fetching comment meta, possibly not community maintainer?

Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "ljdump.py", line 358, in <module>
   ljdump(server, username, password, username)
 File "ljdump.py", line 244, in ljdump
   r.close()
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'close'

(notably, this is my personal journal, so missing permissions shouldn't
happen)

This patch handles this weird case (which will probably never now happen
again)

Signed-off-by: Greg Hewgill <greg@hewgill.com>
version 1.5 includes convertdump.py
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:grahams/ljdump
using getopt for cli option handling.
using getopt for cli option handling.

Fixed handling of security/allowmask tags
Added cli flag for omitting/including secure entries.  Flag kinda wonky
Going to replace all the CLI arg parsing with getopt
added license text

Accepted patch from Carl Johan Crafoord <mail@carljohancrafoord.se>
    - Removed unused "entryLimit" default value, since it was always
      overridden by the required cli argument.
    - Removed condition where the last few entries wouldn't be written out
      to disk.
added command line arguments and some comments and warnings

mostly working now.  need to unhardcode username and breakup limit

WP importer doesn't seem to respect security/allowmask.
In addition, convertdump.py doesn't handle allowmask correctly, need to
observe <security> tag before worrying about allowmask

git-svn-id: svn://svn.icculus.org/quake3/trunk@1588 edf5b092-35ff-0310-97b2-ce42778d08ea

SetTeam fix from Martin Doucha.

"Actually, client->ps.clientNum is unsafe. We had a little hunt for this some
time ago in Tremulous last year (it caused kick failures, annoying popup
windows and other nasty bugs). The problem is that a following spectator gets
full copy of client->ps of the followed player including clientNum. If you then
try to use this "shared" clientNum, you might affect someone else than you
wanted.

r1019 changes are safe as long as bots don't spectate players. However, a brief
grep on current code has revealed unsafe client->ps.clientNum usage in
SetTeam(). If a following spectator uses team command when forced balance is
on, it'll count teams incorrectly and send the error message to the followed
player instead. Here's the fix."

  Fixes Bugzilla #2986.

libraries do not belong to LDFLAGS.
Patch creates separate *LIBS variables for libraries, leaving LDFLAGS for real
flags, like -shared or --as-needed. Also CFLAGS are used when linking:
-m32/-m64 belongs to CFLAGS, not LDFLAGS; linker additionally optimizes output
file when -O* is in flags.

  more or less any input event; fine for the server, not so much use for the
  client

  the methods we're using to sleep at the moment aren't very precise

git-svn-id: svn://svn.icculus.org/quake3/trunk@1378 edf5b092-35ff-0310-97b2-ce42778d08ea

VoIP: attempt at changing voipPower calc and using it for VAD.

The Speex VAD sort of sucks, honestly, or I'm not using it right. Now
 trying this algorithm, after denoising:

    http://lists.xiph.org/pipermail/speex-dev/2006-March/004269.html

And I'll play around to find the threshold for considering a set of frames
 to be "voice" from there.

Also worth noting: we consider the power of the set of frames as a whole, so
 you need to sustain power for 0.25 seconds at a time, or it's not "voice."

git-svn-id: svn://svn.icculus.org/quake3/trunk@1362 edf5b092-35ff-0310-97b2-ce42778d08ea

Changed the protocol for VoIP packets to support legacy clients.

Previously, a legacy client wouldn't get a VoIP packet, but if they did,
 they'd panic and disconnect. Now they ignore them and continue on. This also
 gives us the framework to add other features legacy clients can ignore.

Oh, this also has the benefit of allowing us to store incoming VoIP for
 playback in recorded demos. They'll play the chatter on VoIP clients, and
 be ignored on legacy ones. Huge win.

git-svn-id: svn://svn.icculus.org/quake3/trunk@1288 edf5b092-35ff-0310-97b2-ce42778d08ea

* remove COM_Compress() call on script buffer loaded into memory.  I assume
  this was added in order to save cycles if a script is loaded and then
  parsed multiple times, but it caused line numbers to be reported
  incorrectly for parse errors.  If a script is loaded into memory and
  parsed multiple times then the script itself should be optimized instead
  of doing it at runtime.  Also, there was a possibility of segfault
  due to where this was called.

the build directory. Also builds installer without data files if no

git-svn-id: svn://svn.icculus.org/quake3/trunk@1183 edf5b092-35ff-0310-97b2-ce42778d08ea

* rewrite of the win32 dedicated console:
  1) NET_Sleep() no longer watches for input, Sys_Sleep() added for waiting
     on input.
  2) Added "CtrlHandler" for trapping Ctrl-C and other quit methods not
     handled by signals on windows
  3) Added history support
  4) Added tab completion
  5) Removed automatic cursor/scroll adjustment (too problematic)
  6) Enable mousewheel scrolling
  7) Stop using the InputBuffer for editing

  This seems to work pretty well now, but I jumped the gun on a previous
  commit message by saying you can scroll now without locking up your server.
  That was only true up until the point that a server tried to print to
  the console, at that point it will hang until you release the scroll bar :(
  It may be possible to get around this by using a seperate thread for
  console output, but that's a whole new can of worms.

name: lhasa
description: Layout Handler for ActionScript Applications.  Basically a lower-level set of display related classes to automatically manage laying out child objects.

commit.message: Removed examples (they weren't very good anyhow) and regenerated the documentation.
Merge branch 'syntaxcleanup' into improvements
Various improvements. Reshuffling of method visibility and added methods for measurements.

Tagging release 0.2.1 which makes changes to the way updates are run.  Since the RENDER event is unreliable (see http://www.actionscript.org/forums/archive/index.php3/t-143158.html) we are now using the ENTER_FRAME event to trigger updates.  This is less optimal but now updates are practically guaranteed to run if flagged.

Add Article and basic CRUD support for them.
An Article has a title, a content, is published or not, has a list of comments. 
The index page show published article, and we also have :
- a create page to add article ;
- an edit page to edit existing article :
- a view page to focus on a particular article ;
- a manage page, where the author can publish / unpublish, edit, view summary...
Finally, we added an In emory DAO, which is just a map id/articles

name: modernize
description: Spelling modernizer. Permutes input words, looking for matches in a dictionary.

commit.message: Readme changes.
Readme corrections.
Changes to make work with lein, & other mods.
Smallish Clojure changes.
nthrest => nthnext
Changes to accommodate lazy Clojure (r1287).

Using the excellent c.c.combinatorics code instead of my own
'permutation' library. Some updates to the XSL.
pmap back in m_core; compile generated .java in to-java-static-map.clj.

Added to-java-static-map & a 2.0 stylesheet for replacing text.

to-java-static-map creates a Java class with a static map of words to
their replacements as well as static methods `contains` and `get` for
the standard map operations. to-java-static-map expects to be piped the
output from modernize.main.

text-replace.xsl should be run on a TEI file from the same directory the
Java static map (called Lookup in text-replace) lives.

Note: in modernize.main/run-perms-test, am now using map instead of pmap
-- the latter was eating as much heap space as I would give it (I tried
up to 1GB).
Removed typoed double forward slash from example-cmd.
Add source .clj's to jar; added example invocation in example-cmd.

Finished command-line interface; added build.xml.

CLI has a default for writing successful matches to STDOUT in a simple
format, as well as a verbose-output mode (written to files) as well as
an interactive mode for viewing results & writing results to files.

Refactored file layout -- core functions are in _core, utils in _util,
and the code for -main & CLI is in modernize.clj. Dropped dependency on
my own file-io library; am using contrib.duck-streams now that it's
encoding-aware.
Some way towards CLI interface, including interactive querying.
Typo.
Added README.
Added README.
Some way towards using a fallbacks list...
Refactored file IO, with file-io lib.
Initial imoprt.

added a method which finds related tags.

not to retain the assigned user id. Also removed the User lookup as it was unnecessary
overhead. ActiveRecord already throws an exception if you try to save the object.

Added test case.

Made the amazon_s3.yml file go through ERB before being read by YAML.load.

This allows us to set the Amazon keys through the environment, and not put them under version control.
applied fix as mentioned in http://ar-code.lighthouseapp.com/projects/35/tickets/16-imagescience-gif-thumbnail-references-incorrect

http://ar-code.lighthouseapp.com/projects/35-attachment_fu/tickets/20

use the correct subclass for this spec
use the correct subclass for this spec

Merge branch 'before_francois'
Merge branch 'before_whitespace'
Cleanup the Amazon S3 establish_connection call to accept all aws-s3 options.

Added a 'persistent' amazon s3 connection config parameter to turn off persistent connections if necessary.  The default is the same as the default for the aws-s3 gem, which is to keep persistent connections.

Strip images of all profiles and comments by default. This is the same as "Save for Web" option provided by Photoshop. Picture quality is not affected, but savings are important for small thumbnails i.e. 40kb vs 6kb. An option is provided to disable the feature.

No change if you use Imagescience as it does not support stripping (the underlying FreeImage library knows about EXIF but the ruby wrapper does not).

Fixed a discrepancy in the comments for image_science_processor.rb where it said it was RMagick instead of Image Science.
Added GD Processor and accompanying tests

Can't rescue CompilationError directly: must check the exception's class name instead.

CompilationError is only available if RubyInline was loaded.
Resize to a 1x1 image minimum in the RmagickProcessor.

Also resuce CompilationError when loading the processors.

This prevents ImageScience from causing a system failure if FreeImage can't be found/compiled.

name: resourceful
description: An HTTP library for Ruby that takes advantage of everything HTTP has to offer.

commit.message:
Bug Fix - https not working

The regex scheme comparison wasn't working so I've changed it
to straight string comparison.

In addition, the net/http library doesn't assume port 443 for
https, so you have to explictly state you want to use that
port

Bug fix - age response header was being treated incorrectly

The age header's value is seconds, not a date as we were
treating it.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:paul/resourceful
More caching specs
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:paul/resourceful

Bug fix - host was not changing between redirects.

The Host header is now always taken from the Resource's uri - any
user-defined Host header is ignored. Previously, if you received a
redirect with the only change being the host, you would end in an
"infinite" loop (at least until you could no longer open connections).

Make rake spec work

simple_sinatra_server_spec and the acceptance specs cant be run in the
same go, so make the default spec runner not run them. Add a separate
rake task for those.

Also, added a rake server task that will spawn the server with some
logging, so you can watch the requests being made by the acceptance
specs. Useful for debugging.

Make `rake spec` work

Also, you can run `ruby spec/simple_sinatra_server.rb` in another
console, and watch the requests being made. The spec will attempt to
spawn another server on the same port, and fail silently.
Rename this so it doesnt get run as a spec
Version bump.Some pretty major changes since 0.3.2, so increment the minor version number to reflect that.

Remove the old simple http server

It was a PITA to use, so I wrote one in sinatra, and some acceptance
specs to use it instead. spec/acceptance_spec.rb should be considered
obsolete, and only used as a reference while we rewrite it's specs
against the sinatra server.
Lots more caching specs
Set user agent string
Compact the header spec
Replace the ugly-ass multiple rack apps with a single sinatra app
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:paul/resourceful
Show request headers in debug
Fix broken spec: Resources won't be revalidated unless you specifically ask them to be at the moment.
Factoring out checking for content type - also fixes a bug: Resource would incorrectly raise an Exception if the content type was specified in the default headers
Minor refactoring of Resource - extracting most of the get/put/post/delete implementation to a private method, request
Factoring out the use of Digest::MD5 into a protected method on AbstractCacheManager
A FileCacheManager - stores cache entries on the filesystem
Clean up the request.fetch_response to be actually readable
Refactor do_read_request and do_write_request
Mocks suck
Header constants enhancements

Add headers defined in rcf2616 to the Header class.

    irb(main):001:0>  require 'lib/resourceful/header'
    => true
    irb(main):002:0>  Resourceful::Header::ACCEPT
    => "Accept"
    irb(main):003:0> h =  Resourceful::Header.new(Resourceful::Header::ACCEPT => 'text/html')
    => {"Accept"=>"text/html"}
    irb(main):004:0> h.accept
    => "text/html"
Renaming simple_http_server now it is no longer a spec

Fixing the intermitent problems running thin from specs.

Seems that Rspec does a lot of magic etc. and fork is "odd" within specs.
See http://everburning.com/news/forked-by-rspec/

The test server now starts up once for *every* spec, and is cleanly removed
in an at_exit hook. This has the benfit that the specs should run a bit faster
as well
Changing proxy_details spec to use mocks instead of mutating ENV directly; making proxy_details private
Using the http_proxy environment variable (if set) for proxy details
Increasing sleep time before using Thin - was causing spec failures and added a comment
Fixing mocks requiring the response#is_error? method
A non-followed redirect isn't neccissarily an error
Fork instead of thread, because thread sometimes hangs
Fix to previous commit a515ea4...

Request no-cache and no-store directive implementation

Section 14.9.2 - although there was implementation for no-store in a response, the request can include no-store and expect it to be obeyed as well

Section 14.9.4 - if a request includes the "no-cache" directive, then this should force an end-to-end reload. This is somewhat confusing because no-cache means almost the opposite of what it does when supplied in a response (you can cache, but must revalidate).

Ensuring that if the client provides a max-age Cache Control header, that it is used.

Sections 14.9.3 / 14.9.4 of rfc2616 state that clients can request that a cached response should be revalidated by using the max-age header. In do_read_request we now call Resource#revalidate?(request, response) rather than just calling response.stale?

max-age Cache Control directive should override the Expires header
accoriding to section 14.9.3 of RFC2616

Changing cachability of responses to be correct based on response status code

RFC 2616, section 13.4 states that any responses with status codes other
than 200, 203, 206, 300, 301 or 400 must not be cached.

Changed the check from just looking for any success code to looking for these
codes (apart from 206, which has additional restrictions), and moved the
check to Response#cachable?
Fixing broken spec from a clean clone
Boolean logic is hard
Not a failure if a POST results in a redirect we choose to not follow
Added ability to authenticate with all matching authenticators, rather than the first
Version bump to 0.3.1
Fix a missing require
Add gemspec
Update rakefile

memcache cache manager
merged in Paul's recent changes
Fixes to the gemspec
Fixes to the gemspec
Add gemspec, so github can build our gem
Update the request time, so we only perform the 304 request once after max-age has elapsed, rather than every time

minor refactoring in prep for memcache manage

Fix a bug where responses with max-age=n were never expiring

Make logs a little more informative, by returning the status code, and if it was retrived from the cache
fix a bug by forcing caching to happen on uri strings, rather than Addressable::URI objects
fix a bug where query paramaters were added to the requested urls multiple times
fix a bug where I expected net::http header arrays to be split on values, but they're not. they're always just one element arrays. So now I'm splitting the 'Vary' header myself.
require 'zlib' explicitly
Move BitBucketLogger up a level, and add a simple StdOutLogger
Turn underscores into dashes, so valid symbols convert to standard headers correctly. (:content_type => 'Content-Type')
Refactor to have Resource handle caching. POST, PUT, DELETE now invalidate cache for a resource.
Added rake task to update rubyforge docs
Docs for response
#is_server_error and #is_client_error

Add a little bit of logging; Make caching work for real
Write requests now retry with auth info

remove thin as an installation dependency (only needed for integration specs)
Removed old README and added some examples to the new README

converted all :'content-type' options to :content_type.

I did this because the options hashes should not be the header for the
request.  They should be a way to affect the high level behavior of
the method.  We probably will need a :header options at some point,
though.

removed unnecessary require or 'uri'

Fix TestFileUpload.testTimestamp fractional support

Don't fail upgrading, if the public_html updates can't be written.

This occurs if the config files are owned by a different user than
owns the database, which seems like a reasonable security precaution.

Change to correct directory before loading config in upgrade-master.

Both 'buildbot start' and 'buildbot checkconfig' change to the base directory
before trying to load the config. If a master.cfg depends on this,
'buildbot upgrade-master' should also work there.

Fix TestFileUpload.testTimestamp

Not all filesystems (e.g. ext3) return a meaningful fractional part in
in access and mod time timestamps. Coerce all values to int and just
compare at the second granularity.

Added pipe-escaping doc

Fixes #1799

This patch escapes all pipes in list commands that do not occur by
themself.  This addresses the problem passing in Visual Studio
configuration names, which in their commands are by default patterned
like [...,"Release|Win32",...], which can't be parsed by the shell.

However, this does not touch two different conditions: lone pipes
in a command list (e.g., ['a','|','b'] assumes you want to pipe
the output of a into b) and pipes inside string commands (e.g.,
where the full command is "a | b", not in a list, it is assumed
that you don't want an escaped pipe).

Additionally, this commit adds a skip decorator for the platform,
to clean up that syntax.
